newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Nov 21.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Nov 21.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Thursday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Banks are expected to lift their prime overdraft rates one percentage point to 20.25 percent after Reserve Bank governor Chris Stals announced a similar increase in Bank rate to 17 percent.
- The cabinet has given the green light for revolutionary change to South Africa's water laws, which would abolish the link between water rights and land ownership.
- New Africa Investment Ltd has strengthened its bid for mining house JCI by swelling the membership of its African Mining Consortium to 17, including a number of black-owned mining companies.
- Inflation shot up to 9.1 percent in October from 8.4 percent in September, scaring the bond and currency markets which had expected it to remain below nine percent.

- The state South African Broadcasting Corporation said it planned to eliminate a projected 500 million rand deficit in the next financial year by slashing running costs and asking the government to take over certain high-deficit projects.
- The Reserve Bank said it was raising Bank rate to 17 percent from 16 percent.
- Tiny Rowland, founder and former chairman of Lonrho said that Anglo American Corp's acquisition of a 28 percent stake in Lonrho was unlikely to be approved by the European Commission.
- Fraud running into hundreds of millions of rand will push the Unemployment Insurance Fund into deficit in the financial year to December 31, after management had budgeted for a surplus.
- The spectre of double-digit inflation in the near future loomed large after the announcement that inflation jumped to 9.1 percent in October from September's 8.4 percent.

- The Reserve Bank's announcement last night of a one percentage point increase in Bank rate will see the public paying more on home and car loans, hire purchase contracts, overdrafts and credit cards.
- Legislation to end the private owneship of water will be introduced in South Africa next year.
